facts.text: The 1st appellant, Kuthalia, owner of Sedous Hotel, agreed to sell it to the 1st respondent Oberoi on October 2, 1946 for Rs. 52,75,000/- with earnest money of Rs. 5,00,000/- advanced and completion by January 20, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Lahore was the venue of the earlier forensic episodes. The legal saga formally began in undivided India when the 1st appellant, Kuthalia, the owner of Sedous Hotel, agreed to sell it on October 2, 1946 for a price of Rs. 52,75,000/- to the 1st respondent Oberoi, who became a name in the hotel industry. An earnest money of Rs. 5,00,0001- was advanced and the time fixed for companypletion of the sale was January 20, 1947.

facts.text: Civil Suit No. 514/61 of 1946 filed in Senior Sub-Judge Lahore by Oberoi (1st plaintiff) and Associated Hotels (2nd plaintiff) for recovery of earnest money with interest on alleged breach.

anchor.surface_text: On alleged breach of companytract, Civil Suit No. 514/61 of 1946 was filed in the Court of the Senior Sub-Judge, Lahore, by the 1st respondent  Oberoi  as the 1st plaintiff and the Associated Hotels of India Ltd., as the 2nd plaintiff, for recovery of the earnest money with interest.

facts.text: Trial court decreed Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 with future interest and costs in favor of 1st plaintiff Oberoi; dismissed for 2nd plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: A decree in favour of the 1st plaintiff was made in the sum of Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 with future interest and companyts. So far as the 2nd plaintiff was companycerned the reason for whose presence as party is obscure, if number oblique- the suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal by appellant to Lahore High Court (West Pakistan) successful; suit dismissed in toto on 24th November, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was successfully carried by the present appellant to the High Court of West Pakistan in Lahore since, by the time the trial Courts decree was made the Great Divide had happened with all the blood and tears of political history and traumatic effects on the law and life in both the companyntries. The Lahore High Court, on 24th November, 1949 dismissed the suit in toto

facts.text: Federal Court of Pakistan restored trial court decree on 21-12-1953 reversing High Court.

anchor.surface_text: but, undaunted, Shri Oberoi moved the Federal Court of Pakistan which restored the decree of the trial Court  on 21-12-53  in reversal of the High Courts decree. Thus the final Court in Pakistan at the relevant time granted a decree in favour of the 1st respondent, against the appellant, and that stands.

facts.text: Both parties are evacuees under relevant Pakistani laws.

anchor.surface_text: the companymon case of the parties is that both of them are evacuees under the relevant Pakistani laws.

facts.text: Stay of execution granted by High Court on condition of deposit of Rs. 3,00,000/- on July 16, 1949 and security for balance.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, stay of execution was sought and granted on companydition of deposit of Rs. 3,00,000/- on July, 16 1949 and furnishing of security for the balance.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor (appellant) deposited Rs. 3,00,000/- into executing court but decree-holder not allowed to withdraw before appeal disposal.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant thereto, the sum was deposited by the judgment- debtor into the executing Court, but the decree holder, on objection by the former, was number allowed to withdraw the money before disposal of the appeal.

facts.text: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 promulgated; defines evacuee property vesting in Custodian from March 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: As part of this package, the Pakistan  Administration of Evacuee Property  Ordinance, 1949 was promulgated. ... 6 1  All evacuee property shall vest and shall be deemed always to have vested in the Custodian with effect from the first day of March, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant applied for refund of deposit on December 1, 1949 after winning in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Anyway, the present appellant, when be won in the High Court, moved for refund of the deposit by his application of December 1, 1949.

facts.text: Custodian moved High Court on December 20, 1949 to interdict refund as entitled party evacuee; stayed refund.

anchor.surface_text: Hardly had 4 days passed when the Custodian moved the High Court for interdicting the return of the amount on the score that the entitled party was an evacuee under the aforesaid Ordinance of 1949. The High Court thereupon stayed refund of the deposit to the appellant by an order dated December 20, 1949.

facts.text: Rehabilitation Commissioner requested High Court on January 4, 1954 to deposit Rs. 3L in Treasury as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: From S. JAFRI ESQUIRE C.S.P. REHABILITATION COMMISSIONER... Dated Lahore the 4th January, 1954 Subject-Hedous Hotel Lahore Deposit of Rs. 3 lacs in the High Court of Lahore. ... It is therefore requested that the amount of Rs. 3,00,000 may please be deposited in the Treasury under the detailed head.

facts.text: Defendant Kuthalia moved High Court on January 6, 1954 for adjustment of Rs. 3L towards decree satisfaction, withdraw refund request.

anchor.surface_text: A companyple of days later  January  6  the defendant Kuthalia moved the High Court at Lahore number for refund of the deposit-which he companyld number ask for in view of the Federal Court decree-but praying that the aforesaid amount of Rs. 3,00,000/- may be directed to be adjusted towards satisfaction of the decree

facts.text: Supreme Court of Pakistan directed transfer of Rs. 3L deposit to India under Transfer of Evacuee Deposits Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: the Supreme Court of Pakistan, holding to the companytrary. ... the highest companyrt directed the transfer of the deposit, subject to an innocuous finding by the High Court about both companytestants being evacuees.

facts.text: Deposit of Rs. 3L remains in Pakistan Treasury despite orders.

anchor.surface_text: Anyway, the Supreme Courts order numberwithstanding, the deposit of Rs. 3,00,000/lies idle still, after a lapse of 14 years, in Pakistan Treasury.

facts.text: Oberoi moved Punjab High Court Chandigarh for execution of decree claiming Rs. 10,79,820/-; dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The scene number shifts to India. ... The swollen sum claimed in execution was 10,79,820/4. ... the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh... dismissed the execution petition.

facts.text: Supreme Court of India (Associated Hotels case) held execution under O.45 r.15 misconceived; suit required under s.13 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: the Supreme Court of India where the parties... the Court ruled that the executiorn of the foreign decree, as if it were one of the Supreme Court of India, was misconceived. ... a suit under s. 9 and 13 of the C.P.C.

facts.text: Oberoi filed suit in India for recovery based on Pakistan decree; succeeded in trial court and Delhi High Court (30th August, 1968).

anchor.surface_text: This extinguished the fires of companytroversy regarding executability but ignited the current original suit. Shri Oberoi... filing a regular suit for recovery of the decree amount based on the foreign judgment in his favour and indeed success attended his efforts

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2248 & 2303 of 1968 from Delhi High Court Himachal Bench judgment dated 30th August 1968 in RFA 21/1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2248 2303 of 1968. From the Judgment order dated the 30th August, 1968 of the Delhi High Court  Himachal Bench , Simla in Regular First Appeals No. 21 of 1967 .

facts.text: CA 2248/68 not pressed as counsel concedes decision just.

anchor.surface_text: The other, C.A. 2248 of 1968 has been extinguished by efflux of time and even otherwise is number pressed, since companynsel companycedes the decision to be just .

facts.text: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1957 s.3(1): Property not treated as evacuee property before Jan 1, 1957 not to be treated after.

anchor.surface_text: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1957  XII of 1958  ... s. 3 1  is of strategic signi- ficance and reads- Property number to be treated as evacuee property on or after 1st January, 1957.

facts.text: Court finds decree not treated as evacuee property by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: But has that decree been treated as evacuee property ? The answer is an easy negative. The Custodian never demanded any right qua decree holder number as stepping into the shoes of Shri Oberoi.

facts.text: Execution proceedings prosecuted in good faith; time excluded under s.14 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is beyond cavil that before launching on execution of the Pakistani decree Shri Oberoi had taken advice from two leading Indian lawyers and set about the job diligently. Bonafides is thus writ large in his companyduct.

facts.text: Court directs Rs. 3L deposit adjusted towards decree as of March 31, 1954; balance with interest.

anchor.surface_text: So, the decree amount as on that date, inclusive of companyts incurred, will have to be calculated and Rs. 3 lakhs deducted. The balance will, as stipulated in the decree, carry 5 interest from then on.

facts.text: Appeal CA 2303/68 substantially dismissed but allowed in part for equitable adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is substantially dismissed but is also allowed in part as above indicated. A. 2248 of 1968 is dismissed but numberorder as to companyts.
under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution, granted by the High Court of Delhi.

issues.text: Whether the decree of the Federal Court of Pakistan vested automatically in the Custodian under the Pakistan Ordinance of 1949 thereby depriving the plaintiff Oberoi of locus standi or cause of action to file the suit

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desais submissions logically and sequentially, were three. Firstly, the decree of the Federal Court of Pakistan, which was the foundation of the present action, had vested automatically in the Custodian under the Pakistan Ordinance of 1949 and, therefore, the plaintiff Oberoi had numberright to recover on the basis of the foreign judgment. Absent locus standi or cause of action, his suit was bound to fail and therefore the appeal was bound to be allowed on that initial ground alone.

issues.text: Whether the first point that falls for decision is to decide whether the decree of Shri Oberoi is evacuee property as defined in s. 2(3) of the 1949 Ordinance or property under s.2(5) thereof so that s.6 vests it in the Custodian

anchor.surface_text: The first point that falls for decision therefore is to decide whether the decree of Shri Oberoi is evacuee property as defined in s. 2 3  of the 1949 Ordinance or is Property as defined in s.2 5  thereof. If it is, s. 6 of the said Ordinance will operate to divest the plaintiff of his ownership of the decrce and vest it in the Custodian,

issues.text: Whether the suit is barred by limitation under Art. 117 of the Limitation Act as the six-year period had expired, or saved by ss.14 and 19 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: His second submission was that the six-year period available under Art. 117 of the Indian Limitation Act for a suit upon a foreign decree had long ago expired, reckoned from the date when the Federal Court of Pakistan granted the present plaintiff a decree. By simple arithmetic he is right but the plaintiff has sought to salvage his action from the clutches of limitation by reliance on ss. 14 and 19 of the Indian Limitation Act.

issues.text: Whether the time spent in prosecuting the prior execution proceedings can be excluded under s.14 of the Limitation Act due to lack of jurisdiction in the executing court

anchor.surface_text: Section 14, which neatly fits in, is simple in its ingredients, to the extent we are called upon to companysider. It is a sine qua number of a claim unders.14 that the earlier proceeding is prosecuted in good faith. It is beyond cavil that before launching on execution of the Pakistani decree Shri Oberoi had taken advice from two leading Indian lawyers and set about the job diligently.

issues.text: Whether there was acknowledgement of liability under s.19 Limitation Act by the judgment-debtor to save limitation

anchor.surface_text: Section 19, to help renew limitation., requires, as rightly stressed by Shri Desai, an intention to own a subsisting liability by the debtor to the particular creditor. Mere chronicles of litigations and recitals of documentary events, it is argued, cannot be regarded as acknowledgement if the whole drift of the writing is a denial of the plaintiffs claim.

holdings.text: The decree of the Federal Court of Pakistan did not vest in the Custodian as evacuee property under the Pakistan Ordinance of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The first point that falls for decision therefore is to decide whether the decree of Shri Oberoi is evacuee property as defined in s. 2 3  of the 1949 Ordinance or is Property as defined in s.2 5  thereof. If it is, s. 6 of the said Ordinance will operate to divest the plaintiff of his ownership of the decrce and vest it in the Custodian,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree not defined as evacuee property under s.2(3) or property under s.2(5) of 1949 Ordinance; not treated as such by Custodian before 1957; s.3(1) of 1957 Act bars post-1957 treatment if not prior.

holdings.text: The plaintiff retains locus standi to sue on the foreign decree as it is not evacuee property vested in Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desais submissions logically and sequentially, were three. Firstly, the decree of the Federal Court of Pakistan, which was the foundation of the present action, had vested automatically in the Custodian under the Pakistan Ordinance of 1949 and, therefore, the plaintiff Oberoi had numberright to recover on the basis of the foreign judgment. Absent locus standi or cause of action, his suit was bound to fail and therefore the appeal was bound to be allowed on that initial ground alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian never claimed or treated decree as evacuee property; no demand of rights as decree-holder; consistent with s.13 CPC conclusiveness absent exceptions.

holdings.text: Foreign judgment is conclusive and enforceable by suit under s.13 CPC as no exceptions apply.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, a suit on fact of a foreign decree is sustainable and s. 13C.P.C.,sets out the limitations on the amplitude of the right. This proposition is number disputed but what Shri Desai argues is that the decree being evacuee property under the Pakistan Ordinance, it has already vested in the Custodian by statutory Operation, so much so the plaintiff has long ago ceased to be decree-holder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: None of s.13 exceptions attracted; prima facie unassailable despite evacuee argument rejected.

holdings.text: Suit not barred by limitation under Art.117 as time excluded under s.14 Limitation Act.

holdings.text: Execution proceedings lacked jurisdiction due to nature of foreign decree, attracting s.14 exclusion.

Shri Sens strenuous submission summed up fairly is that undefined rules of equity are unruly horses and in India legal rights cannot be chased out by nebulous numberions of good companyscience labelled equity.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Desais submissions logically and sequentially, were three. Firstly, the decree of the Federal Court of Pakistan, which was the foundation of the present action, had vested automatically in the Custodian under the Pakistan Ordinance of 1949 and, therefore, the plaintiff Oberoi had numberright to recover on the basis of the foreign judgment. Absent locus standi or cause of action, his suit was bound to fail and therefore the appeal was bound to be allowed on that initial ground alone.
